newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's MFK-Renaissance mulls Svyazinvest bid.
newsitem.headline: Russia's MFK-Renaissance mulls Svyazinvest bid.

text.p: ICFI Bank, a unit of Russia's Uneximbank, and investment bank Renaissance Capital are considering bidding for a 25 percent plus one share stake in telecom holding Svyazinvest, officials said on Wednesday.

Uneximbank head Vladimir Potanin said ICFI (Bank MFK) was talking with financial investors, not foreign telecom operators, and was considering putting up $500 million of its own funds for the state-held stake, which has a starting price of $1.18 billion.
"If we win, we will take part in management," Potanin said after a news conference to announce a merger between ICFI and Renaissance, Bank MFK-Renaissance.
Potanin said his group was discussing the deal with Deutsche Bank, among other financial groups.

"If the decision (to bid) is made, then we intend to use $500 million of our own funds, and raise the rest with the help of Russian and foreign investors. However, at this time, a final decision has not been taken."
Svyazinvest has controlling stakes in 88 regional and other telecom companies and is considered a key to the Russian domestic telecom industry and a crown jewel enterprise.
The government auction for the first stake ends July 25 and Russia plans to sell another 24 percent stake thereafter.
Renaissance Capital head Boris Jordan, who will manage the merged Bank MFK-Renaissance, told reporters there were more than five potential Svyazinvest bidders.
"From what I know there are multiple players -- more than five," Jordan told reporters.
He declined to comment on whether MFK-Renaissance would bid for the second stake, which will be open only to Russian investors.
Uneximbank is known in Russian as Oneximbank.
